The concept of lines and angles is used in many real-life situations, such as measuring the angle of a door or the angle of a swing. By understanding the properties of lines and angles, we can solve problems and make informed decisions.
An angle is formed by two rays sharing a common endpoint called the vertex.
To draw an angle, we need to join two points with a straight line and mark the vertex.

An acute angle is an angle whose measure is less than 90°.
To identify an acute angle, we need to check if the angle is less than 90°.
For example, an angle of 50° is an acute angle.
An obtuse angle is an angle whose measure is greater than 90° and less than 180°.
To identify an obtuse angle, we need to check if the angle is greater than 90° and less than 180°.
For example, an angle of 110° is an obtuse angle.
A reflex angle is an angle whose measure is greater than 180° and less than 360°.
To identify a reflex angle, we need to check if the angle is greater than 180° and less than 360°.
For example, an angle of 210° is a reflex angle.

A point determines a location. It is denoted by a capital letter. A line segment corresponds to the shortest distance between two points. The line segment joining points S and T is denoted by ST. A line is obtained when a line segment like ST is extended on both sides indefinitely; it is denoted by ST or sometimes by a single small letter like m. A ray is a portion of a line starting at a point D and going in one direction indefinitely. It is denoted by DP where P is another point on the ray.

An angle can be visualised as two rays starting from a common starting point. Two rays OP and OM form the angle ∠POM (also called ∠MOP); here, O is called the vertex of the angle, and the rays OP and OM are called the arms of the angle.

The size of an angle is the amount of rotation or turn needed about the vertex to rotate one ray of the angle onto the other ray of the angle. The sizes of angles can be measured in degrees. One full rotation or turn is considered as 360 degrees and denoted as 360°.

An obtuse angle is an angle that measures more than 90 degrees but less than 180 degrees. It is formed by two rays or line segments that intersect at an obtuse angle.

content_blocks.text: An angle is formed by two rays sharing a common endpoint called the vertex. The measure of an angle is the number of 1° unit parts it contains inside it.
To assign precise measures to angles, mathematicians divided the angle in the centre of the circle into 32 equal angles or parts, with each part measuring 1 degree.
For example, an angle that contains 30 units of 1° angle has a measure of 30°.
A full turn has 360 degrees, a straight angle has 180 degrees, and a right angle has 90 degrees.
The reason why we use 360 degrees today is not fully known, but it is believed to be related to ancient calendars and the use of sexagesimal numbers.
A protractor is a tool used to measure angles in degrees, and it can be either a circle divided into 360 equal parts or a half circle divided into 180 equal parts.
